name: Electric Reliability Council of Texas
qualitative_note: Energy-only market. 2023 prices elevated ($55.50/MWh) before massive 2024 buildout. Supply response in motion — 7.8 GW added in 2023, nearly doubling to ~14 GW in 2024.
source_price: E3 2024 ERCOT Market Update (ERCOT North Hub DA avg, 2023)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 3,553 / battery 1,924 / wind 1,461 / gas 820 MW)

name: Southwest Power Pool
qualitative_note: Wind-dominated additions in 2023. Prices stable around $26/MWh. Large wind resource base keeps prices low despite modest queue throughput.
source_price: SPP 2023 State of the Market Report (DA system avg)

name: Midcontinent ISO
qualitative_note: Solar buildout accelerating in 2023. Prices ~$35/MWh (RT estimate, ~$37 all-in minus ~$2 PRA). Capacity additions nearly doubled from 2023 to 2024.
source_price: Potomac Economics 2023 MISO State of the Market (~$37 all-in minus ~$2 PRA, estimated)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 2,758 / wind 1,386 / gas 690 MW)

name: California ISO
qualitative_note: Battery storage buildout already substantial in 2023 (3 GW). Prices estimated ~$45/MWh DA energy-only (~$65 all-in less RA costs). Mandate-driven additions (SB 100).
source_price: CAISO DMM 2023 Annual Report (~$65 all-in; energy-only estimated at ~$45/MWh)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (battery 3,052 / solar 2,545 / wind 95 MW)

name: PJM Interconnection
qualitative_note: Strong 2023 additions (7.9 GW) driven by gas CC cycle and solar. Prices $31/MWh. Capacity additions dropped to 4.1 GW in 2024 as queue congestion worsened. BRA 2025/26 at $269.92/MW-day signals the coming price shock.
source_price: Monitoring Analytics 2023 PJM State of the Market (RT LW avg LMP, $31.08)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 3,487 / gas CC 3,355 / wind 594 / gas CT 380 / battery 60 MW)

name: New York ISO
qualitative_note: Prices estimated ~$45/MWh wholesale (~$58 all-in minus ~$8 ICAP; zonal avg estimate). Minimal new supply. Offshore wind procurement delays continue.
source_price: Potomac Economics 2023 NYISO SOM (~$58 all-in; energy-only estimated at ~$45/MWh)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (wind 557 / solar 313 / battery 53 MW)

name: ISO New England
qualitative_note: Lower prices in 2023 ($36.82) than 2024 ($41.47) — 13% YoY increase. Minimal additions. Gas dependence + pipeline constraints drive winter spikes.
source_price: ISO-NE IMM 2023 Annual Markets Report (DA avg, $36.82)

name: Electric Reliability Council of Texas
qualitative_note: Energy-only market with streamlined interconnection. Added ~14 GW in 2024 (EIA-860M) — more than any other ISO — driven by solar, battery, and gas. Queue completion rate 3–5× higher than peers.
source_price: E3 2024 ERCOT Market Update (ERCOT North Hub DA avg)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 7,277 / battery 4,264 / wind 1,735 / gas 697 MW). Note: industry sources (E3, IEEFA, Dallas Fed, Amperon) report ~18.7 GW pending final filings.
source_peak: ERCOT (settled value, Aug 20 2024; below 2023 record of 85.5 GW)

name: Southwest Power Pool
qualitative_note: Wind-dominated resource mix with lowest wholesale prices. Modest new additions in 2024 but historically strong wind buildout. Queue reforms underway.
source_price: SPP 2024 Annual State of the Market Report (DA system avg)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (wind 902 / solar 225 MW). Note: industry sources (SPP ELCC Report, Amperon) report ~2.5 GW pending final filings.
source_peak: SPP 2024 State of the Market (est. ~3% below 2023)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); Brattle Scorecard reports <10% for 2018–2020

name: Midcontinent ISO
qualitative_note: Largest US ISO by geographic footprint. Solar installations doubled in 2024. Queue reforms (MTEP cycles) improving throughput, but ~72% of projects still never reach fruition.
source_price: Potomac Economics 2024 MISO State of the Market (RT avg LMP)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 6,273 / wind 625 / gas 186 / battery 54 MW)

name: California ISO
qualitative_note: Battery storage leader — added 3.6 GW of batteries in 2024 (EIA-860M). High additions driven by state mandates, but only ~10% of queue projects reach operation. Duck curve dynamics suppress midday prices.
source_price: CAISO DMM Q3/Q4 2024 Quarterly Reports (est. annual DA avg)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (battery 3,638 / solar 2,688 / wind 143 / gas 48 MW)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); Concentric Energy Advisors; Brattle Scorecard reports <10% for 2018–2020

name: PJM Interconnection
qualitative_note: Largest US ISO by peak demand. Data center load growth outpacing new supply. Queue backlog of 260+ GW with only 12% completion rate. 'Speed to power' crisis identified by RMI.
source_price: Monitoring Analytics 2024 PJM State of the Market (RT LW avg LMP)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 3,817 / wind 189 / battery 54 MW)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); RMI; Brattle Scorecard reports <10% for 2018–2020

name: New York ISO
qualitative_note: Extreme zonal price divergence — NYC (Zone J) averages ~$50+/MWh while upstate ~$25. Minimal new supply despite CLCPA mandates. Offshore wind procurement delays and Article 10 siting friction.
source_price: NYISO 'Impact of National & Global Conditions on Electricity Prices in New York' white paper (2024 avg wholesale price)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 915 / wind 130 / battery 20 MW)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); Brattle Scorecard reports <10% for 2018–2020

name: ISO New England
qualitative_note: Energy + FCA capacity cost ~$51/MWh (comparable basis). Published $87/MWh total includes RECs, RGGI, ancillary, and transmission. Vineyard Wind blade failure (July 2024) shut down all 136 MW for ~6 months; operational contribution in 2024 was severely limited. Gas dependence + pipeline constraints drive winter price spikes. Worst queue completion rate nationally.
source_price: ISO-NE Internal Market Monitor 2024 Annual Markets Report (DA avg)
source_capacity: EIA-860M Jan 2026 vintage (solar 421 / gas 65 / battery 25 MW)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); Brattle/AEU Scorecard reports <10% for 2018–2020

name: PJM Interconnection
confidence: BRA 2025/26 locked in at $269.92/MW-day (~$18/MWh capacity adder). Wholesale and capacity additions estimated.
qualitative_note: BRA 2025/26 capacity price jumped 9× to $269.92/MW-day — the consequence of not building. All-in cost rises from ~$36 to ~$52/MWh. Queue backlog persists. Data center demand still growing.
source_price: Wholesale: estimated ~$34/MWh (similar to 2024). Capacity: BRA 2025/26 at $269.92/MW-day (S&P Global, PJM official report)
source_capacity: Estimated ~4,000 MW (similar to 2024 EIA-860M, queue still clogged)
source_peak: Estimated ~155 GW (trending up from 152.6 GW in 2024 due to data center growth)
source_queue: LBNL Queued Up (2000–2019 cohort); queue backlog persists

name: Midcontinent ISO
confidence: PRA 2025/26 locked in. Summer $666.50/MW-day (22× increase). Annualized ~$217/MW-day (~$9/MWh capacity adder, 10× increase). Wholesale and capacity additions estimated.
qualitative_note: MISO PRA 2025/26 prices exploded — summer capacity cost jumped 22× to $666.50/MW-day under the new Reliability-Based Demand Curve. Annualized average ~$217/MW-day (10× increase from $21/MW-day in 2024/25). Driven by tightening reserves, plant retirements, and the same structural underbuilding dynamics as PJM.
source_price: Wholesale: estimated ~$31/MWh (similar to 2024). Capacity: PRA 2025/26 (Enel North America, Utility Dive, RTO Insider). Summer $666.50/MW-day, annualized ~$217/MW-day.

name: Electric Reliability Council of Texas
confidence: $37.57 computed from 12 months of EIA STEO (ERCOT North Hub DA). Capacity from Modo Energy annual report. No annual SOM published yet.
qualitative_note: Energy-only market. Price rose from $27.33 to $37.57 in 2025 — supply response taking a breather after massive 2024 buildout (14 GW). Battery and solar still dominating additions.
source_price: EIA STEO monthly wholesale data (ERCOT North Hub DA, 12-month avg)
source_capacity: Modo Energy 2025 Annual Report (5,200 MW battery + 4,500 MW solar + wind/gas)

name: Southwest Power Pool
confidence: $37.91 computed from 12 months of EIA STEO (SPP South Hub DA). Capacity estimated proportionally to 2024.
qualitative_note: Wind-dominated resource mix. Prices jumped ~38% from $27.56 to $37.91 driven by gas price increases and demand growth. Modest additions continue.
source_price: EIA STEO monthly wholesale data (SPP South Hub DA, 12-month avg)

name: California ISO
confidence: Estimated from CAISO DMM Q1–Q3 quarterly reports. Capacity from CAISO 2025 Year in Review. No annual SOM published yet.
qualitative_note: Battery storage buildout continues — 4,260 MW of batteries in 2025 (CAISO Year in Review). Wholesale prices declined from $38 to ~$35 due to solar oversupply suppressing midday prices.
source_price: CAISO DMM Q1–Q3 2025 Quarterly Reports (estimated annual DA avg)
source_capacity: CAISO 2025 Year in Review (includes 4,260 MW battery)
source_peak: Estimated ~49 GW (trending up from 48.3 GW in 2024)

name: New York ISO
confidence: Estimated from Potomac Economics quarterly reports + EIA monthly. Gas-driven winter spikes pushed annual average up. Conservative energy-only estimate.
qualitative_note: High-price year driven by gas-fueled winter spikes. Energy-only estimate ~$55/MWh. Minimal new supply despite CLCPA mandates. Offshore wind delays persist.
source_price: Potomac Economics quarterly reports + EIA monthly wholesale data (2025 avg, energy-only estimate)

name: ISO New England
confidence: Estimated from ISO Newswire monthly data. Winter spikes ($130+/MWh Dec/Jan/Feb) pulled annual average up significantly from 2024's $41.47.
qualitative_note: Winter price spikes ($130+/MWh Dec/Jan/Feb) drove annual energy-only average from $41.47 to ~$55/MWh. Gas dependence + pipeline constraints amplified by cold winter. Minimal new capacity. Worst queue completion rate nationally.
source_price: ISO Newswire monthly wholesale data (2025 avg, energy-only estimate)
source_peak: Estimated ~25 GW (trending up from 24.4 GW in 2024)

name: Texas
qualitative_note: Single-state ISO. Energy-only market with streamlined interconnection drove 18.7 GW of additions in 2024 — more than any other state.

name: California
qualitative_note: Single-state ISO. Battery storage leader (4.2 GW in 2024). Additions driven by SB 100 mandates, not price signals.

name: New York
qualitative_note: Single-state ISO. Extreme NYC vs upstate price divergence. CLCPA mandates but siting friction (Article 10) stalls projects.

name: Illinois
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (Ameren IL) and PJM (ComEd). Strong solar buildout downstate. CEJA (Climate and Equitable Jobs Act) driving utility-scale solar.

name: Indiana
qualitative_note: Spans MISO and PJM. Solar replacing retiring coal. Data center demand growing in central Indiana.

name: Minnesota
qualitative_note: Strong wind resource. Xcel Energy driving clean energy portfolio. Legislature passed 100% clean energy standard.

name: Michigan
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (most of state) and PJM (small zone). 100% clean energy law passed 2023 driving solar expansion.

name: Iowa
qualitative_note: Wind energy leader (~60% of generation from wind). Data center growth in Des Moines metro driving new demand.

name: Wisconsin
qualitative_note: Moderate solar growth. We Energies and Alliant driving utility-scale projects.

name: Louisiana
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (Entergy) and SPP. Gas-heavy additions serving LNG export and petrochemical load growth.

name: Mississippi
qualitative_note: Emerging solar market. Entergy Mississippi driving utility-scale solar procurement.

name: Missouri
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (Ameren MO) and SPP. Ameren driving solar procurement to replace coal retirements.

name: Arkansas
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (Entergy) and SPP. Solar growing but still modest.

name: Kentucky
qualitative_note: Spans MISO (LG&E) and PJM (EKPC, DEOK). Coal-dependent state with slow transition.

name: Virginia
qualitative_note: Data center capital of the world (Loudoun County). VCEA mandates driving massive solar procurement. Dominion Energy's offshore wind project (2.6 GW) under construction.

name: Pennsylvania
qualitative_note: Large system but moderate buildout relative to peak. Solar growth in south-central PA. Gas generation well-established.

name: Ohio
qualitative_note: SB 52 (2021) gave townships veto power over wind and solar. Local opposition slowing renewable siting despite PJM queue.

name: New Jersey
qualitative_note: Aggressive offshore wind targets (11 GW by 2040). Land-constrained — most solar is community/rooftop scale.

name: Maryland
qualitative_note: Clean energy mandate (50% by 2030) driving solar. Data center growth in Frederick/Montgomery counties.

name: West Virginia
qualitative_note: Coal-dependent. Very limited renewable development. State policy hostile to wind siting.

name: North Carolina
qualitative_note: Small PJM footprint (Duke Carolinas). Most NC generation is outside organized markets. HB 951 driving solar growth.

name: Delaware
qualitative_note: Small state with limited land for utility-scale projects.

name: Oklahoma
qualitative_note: Major wind state with excellent resource. Growing solar and battery co-location. Permitting generally favorable.

name: Kansas
qualitative_note: Wind-dominant. Strong capacity additions relative to system size. Rural siting generally permissive.

name: Nebraska
qualitative_note: Public power state (NPPD, OPPD). Wind additions steady. Unique ownership structure (no IOUs).

name: New Mexico
qualitative_note: Spans SPP and non-ISO territory. Energy Transition Act driving coal replacement with solar and wind.

name: Massachusetts
qualitative_note: High prices, minimal building. Offshore wind procurement delays. Land-constrained for utility-scale solar. Next-Gen RFPs proceeding slowly.

name: Connecticut
qualitative_note: Highest electricity costs in New England. Siting challenges for both onshore and offshore wind.

name: Maine
qualitative_note: Strong wind resource but local opposition. Rejected CMP transmission corridor. Small market limits utility-scale development.

name: New Hampshire
qualitative_note: Minimal new development. Northern Pass transmission rejected. Limited policy support for renewables.

name: Vermont
qualitative_note: Smallest New England state by demand. Strong Act 250 environmental review limits siting. Most generation is distributed/community solar.

name: Rhode Island
qualitative_note: Tiny land area limits utility-scale projects. Block Island Wind Farm was first US offshore wind (30 MW). Act on Climate goals unmatched by buildout.

name: Texas
qualitative_note: TX state view uses industry sources (E3, IEEFA): 18.7 GW. ISO view uses EIA-860M only: 14.0 GW — difference reflects generators not yet filed with EIA. Energy-only market with streamlined interconnection.
source_peak: ERCOT system peak (settled value, Aug 20 2024; below 2023 record of 85.5 GW)

name: California
qualitative_note: Single-state ISO. Battery storage leader (4.2 GW in 2024). Additions driven by SB 100 mandates, not price signals.
source_capacity: EIA-860M plant state; CAISO Battery Storage Report
